definitions.definition: to turn over and over and move in a particular direction; to make a round object do this

examples.text: The ball rolled down the hill.
Tears rolled down her cheeks.
We watched the waves rolling onto the beach.
The marble rolled behind the sofa.
Delivery men were rolling barrels across the yard.
He rolled the boulder aside.

definitions.definition: to turn over and over or round and round while remaining in the same place; to make something do this

examples.text: Her eyes rolled.
a dog rolling in the mud
She **rolled her eyes** *(= to show surprise or disapproval)*.
He was rolling a pencil between his fingers.

definitions.definition: to turn over to face a different direction; to make somebody/something do this
definitions.sensetop: roll overroll over onto somethingroll onto somethingroll somebody/something overroll somebody/something over onto somethingroll somebody/something onto somethingroll something

examples.text: She rolled over to let the sun brown her back.
He quickly rolled over and got to his feet.
I rolled over onto my stomach.
He rolled onto his back.
The paramedics rolled him over to make it easier for him to breathe.
I rolled the baby over onto its stomach.
She rolled the patient onto his side.
She rolled her car in a 100 mph crash.

definitions.definition: to throw dice in a game

examples.text: Each player rolls their dice.
Players take turns rolling a die and moving around the board.
Roll a six to start.

definitions.definition: to move smoothly on wheels or as if on wheels; to make something do this

examples.text: The car began to roll back down the hill.
The traffic rolled slowly forwards.
Tanks rolled triumphantly into the city.
He rolled the trolley across the room.

definitions.definition: to move or flow forward in a steady way

examples.text: Mist was rolling in from the sea.
In the afternoon, dark clouds rolled in.
The fog was rolling off the moors.
the sound of waves rolling in to the shore

definitions.definition: to make something/yourself into the shape of a ball or tube
definitions.sensetop: roll something into somethingroll something up

examples.text: I rolled the string into a ball.
Roll the mixture into small balls and place them on a baking tray.
We rolled up the carpet.
a rolled-up newspaper
The hedgehog **rolled (up) into a ball**.
Armadillos roll into a ball to protect themselves from harm.
He rolled the paper into a tight ball.
She carried the magazine tightly rolled up in her hand.

definitions.definition: to make a cigarette yourself by putting tobacco on special paper and forming it into a tube

examples.text: He leaned on the table and rolled a cigarette.
I always **roll my own** *(= make my own cigarettes)*.

definitions.definition: to fold the edge of a piece of clothing, etc. over and over on itself to make it shorter
definitions.sensetop: roll something uproll something downroll something + adv./prep.

examples.text: Roll up your sleeves.
Alice rolled down her sock to reveal a scar on her ankle.
She rolled her jeans to her knees.

definitions.definition: to make something flat by pushing something heavy over it

examples.text: Roll the pastry on a floured surface.

definitions.definition: to wrap or cover somebody/something/yourself in something
definitions.sensetop: roll somebody/something/yourself in somethingroll somebody/something/yourself up in something

examples.text: Roll the meat in the breadcrumbs.
He rolled himself up in the blanket.

definitions.definition: to move or make something move from side to side

examples.text: He walked with a rolling gait.
The ship was rolling heavily to and fro.

definitions.definition: to make a long continuous sound

examples.text: rolling drums
Thunder rolled.
to **roll your r’s** *(= by letting your tongue  with each ‘r’ sound)
From the walls a trumpet sounded, a drum rolled and the gate swung open.
You have to roll your r's when speaking Spanish.
The sky had darkened and thunder rolled in the west.

definitions.definition: when a machine rolls or somebody rolls it, it operates

examples.text: They had to repeat the scene because the cameras weren't rolling.
Roll the cameras!

definitions.definition: to behave in a particular way

examples.text: She surprised her fans with a completely new look because **that's how she rolls**.

definitions.definition: to have a lot of money
to make something start happening; to make sure that something continues to happen
used to say that some people will be punished because of something that has happened
used to suggest to a group of people that you should all start doing something or going somewhere
ready to start

examples.text: The show is just about ready to roll.

definitions.definition: combined in one person or thing

examples.text: Banks are several businesses rolled into one.

definitions.definition: laughing a lot

examples.text: She soon had us rolling in the aisles.

definitions.definition: likely to be very shocked or angry

examples.text: My father would roll over his grave if he knew.

definitions.definition: a person who moves from place to place, job to job, etc. does not have a lot of money, possessions or friends but is free from responsibilities
to be easy to say or pronounce

examples.text: It's not a name that exactly rolls off the tongue, is it?

definitions.definition: used to say that you want something to happen or arrive soon

examples.text: Roll on Friday!

definitions.definition: to prepare to work or fight
to adapt yourself to a difficult situation
